editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

wiÅ¿dom and goodneÅ¿s is Å¿uch, that he will both find out time, and means to undeceive poor Å¿ouls that belong to him, and will deliver them out of the Å¿nare of Satan, who captivates them for a little Å¿pace (while his pleaÅ¿ure is) for their humbling; and leaving this work in Gods hand, and thy Å¿elf alÅ¿o,

div.p: THe next Scripture that I produced for the confirmation of the Diety of JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, (after Joh. 8. 58.) was Rev. 1. 8. I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending, Å¿aith the Lord, which is, and which was, and which is to come, the Almighty.

As for learned Interpreters, though I honour them much, yet it hath not been my cuÅ¿tom to bottom the Å¿enÅ¿e that I put upon Scriptures upon them; but to prove it from the Scripture, either the Text it Å¿elf or context, or Å¿ome other parallel place; therefore he might have Å¿pared his labour in citing Authors, unleÅ¿s I had provoked him thereto.

div.p:
The Major hath an infallible truth in it: for the Scripture makes ChriÅ¿t to be principally the object of a ChriÅ¿tians faith, as he is the Son of God. 1. Which places do all Å¿hew that we through Å¿in are primarily the Captives of God, as a King and Judge offended; and that only Å¿econdarily we are Captives to the devil and other enemies as to Gods MiniÅ¿ters and Servants, though enemies, to which we are committed; for without commiÅ¿Å¿ion and permiÅ¿Å¿ion we are taught, that the greateÅ¿t tyrants can effect nothing againÅ¿t Gods Elect; and the very devils themÅ¿elves, could not go into the herd of Å¿wine without leave; therefore the price paid to God to Å¿atisfie him is the principal thing in redemption.

It is alÅ¿o to be underÅ¿tood, that theÅ¿e two, To be redeemed from God, and to be redeemed to God, will conÅ¿iÅ¿t very well together; for the captivity of the Elect, is not like the captivation of a perÅ¿on taken in war, and detained by the enemy, from whom when he is redeemed, he is totally alienated and Å¿eparated, and hath no more to do with him: nor is it like the captivation of a perÅ¿on, who is violently and unjuÅ¿tly detained in the hand of a cruel one, who tyrannizeth over him after the manner of Pharaoh, who laid unjuÅ¿tly heavy burdens upon the children of IÅ¿rael, from whom (if he be once freed) he is totally withdrawn from Å¿uch an one, and divided, never

Object. 5.

It is further aÅ¿Å¿erted, that it is God that gave ChriÅ¿t to redeem men, and if there be any Å¿atisfaction given to God by ChriÅ¿t, God himÅ¿elf is the author of it, and gave it to himÅ¿elf; if he gave it to himÅ¿elf, he was Å¿atisfied before,

Sol. God muÅ¿t be looked upon as one that dearly loves the captivated elect perÅ¿ons, who had Å¿inned againÅ¿t him, and would not have them periÅ¿h; and withall he muÅ¿t be looked upon as one that dearly loved juÅ¿tice and truth, and cannot Å¿uffer either of them to be violated; for they are himÅ¿elf, as dear to him as himÅ¿elf; therefore he provides that JuÅ¿tice and Truth, and the life and welfare of Å¿uch poor captives, may conÅ¿iÅ¿t together; and becauÅ¿e he Å¿ees it impoÅ¿Å¿ible by any thing that the electcan do, who had offended, becauÅ¿e they are without Å¿trength, and can make no Å¿atisfaction for any treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, therefore he himÅ¿elf in his wiÅ¿dome and love to the Elect, and in his love to JuÅ¿tice and Truth, findes out a way to Å¿ave them from ruine, and to Å¿atisfie theÅ¿e. And that is by ChriÅ¿t, whom he Å¿ends; and this is all his deÅ¿igne, and he lookes for no further gain, nor advantage to himÅ¿elf, but that his goodneÅ¿Å¿e and righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and truth might be glorified together, in the Å¿alvation of the Elect,

Object. 6.

It is likewiÅ¿e aÅ¿Å¿erted, that there is an unÅ¿atisfied conÅ¿cience in men; men having Å¿inned, cannot diÅ¿cerne how Gods heart can be towards them without Å¿atisfaction; therefore the Scripture Å¿peaks of propitiation through ChriÅ¿ts bloud, and of atonement by his death, condeÅ¿cending therein to mans infirmity, which could not otherwiÅ¿e apprehend how God could communicate life and glory to men after they had Å¿inned, without being firÅ¿t appeaÅ¿ed and pacified by ChriÅ¿ts blood: But if things be rightly conÅ¿idered in themÅ¿elves, as in truth they are, ChriÅ¿t dyed not to reconcile us to God, but to heal us of an evill conÅ¿cience, and that we might know that God loved us after we had Å¿inned, as well as he did before, by the gift of ChriÅ¿t, who is the manifeÅ¿tation of the Fathers love after the fall which the Elect could not be perÅ¿waded of, but by a pledge of it; Therefore it is Å¿aid that ChriÅ¿t Å¿hed his bloud to purge our conÅ¿cience from dead works, to Å¿erve the living God, Heb. 9. 14. and not to Å¿atisfie God.

Sol. It will readily be confeÅ¿Å¿ed, that it was an end of ChriÅ¿ts dying, to reconcile men to God, and that they might have the anÅ¿wer of a good

1. What need would there have been that ChriÅ¿t Å¿hould have dyed at all, if only Å¿atisfaction to mens conÅ¿ciences concerning Gods goodneÅ¿Å¿e and love to fallen creatures had been intended therein. 2. The love of God repreÅ¿ented unto men in giving ChriÅ¿t, is much leÅ¿Å¿ened to them in the repreÅ¿entation, if ChriÅ¿t were only given to Å¿atisfie their hearts in reference to their fears of God, & not to Å¿atisfie Gods juÅ¿tice; if there were no need of ChriÅ¿t, in reference to any danger they were in, in regard of God, if God could or would have pardoned Å¿in without him, and his juÅ¿tice and truth could have remitted it.

5. How came thoÅ¿e fears in the heart of man after the fall, after Å¿inne committed? 6. TheÅ¿e fears and terrors of the Elect, before ChriÅ¿ts

And if Å¿o, are not both the one and the other that wrath of God which God poures into the Å¿oul becauÅ¿e of Å¿inne which he proÅ¿ecutes againÅ¿t men? are they not puniÅ¿hments for Å¿in from God? is not Gods righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e therein revealed againÅ¿t Å¿in, & the truth of God in the threatning fulfilled, which did reach to both Elect and Reprobate? And if Å¿o, how can God remove them from the Elect through ChriÅ¿t, without Å¿atisfaction given by ChriÅ¿t, and yet Å¿uffer them to lie upon the Reprobate, without palpable unrighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and untruth, when the threatning, viz. 7. Q. 2. The Å¿econd thing that I promiÅ¿ed to Å¿peak to, is this, that Å¿eeing Å¿ome Å¿atisfaction muÅ¿t be given to God, in reference to a treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e committed, and an offence taken, and a threatning given out upon Å¿uppoÅ¿ition, and afterward inflicted upon the perpetration of Å¿uch an evill, what Å¿atisfaction it is that is neceÅ¿Å¿arie: whether any Å¿atisfaction will Å¿erve, or whether it muÅ¿t be a proportionable Å¿atisfaction.

Sol. 1. It cannot be denyed but that God is the Å¿overaigne Lord over all, and hath none above him to appoint him, or to enjoyne him, to give rules and laws to him, how he ought to walk towards the creature; none can limit or reÅ¿traine him, or Å¿et bounds unto him; but his will (which is always holy and juÅ¿t and good) is the rule that he acts by; and he doth whatÅ¿oever pleaÅ¿eth him, PÅ¿. 115. 3. & further then he Å¿ets bounds to himÅ¿elf, he cannot be bound up to any thing, or by any one; and further then he reÅ¿trains and limits himÅ¿elf, he cannot be reÅ¿trained and limited

Therefore he might at the firÅ¿t (if it had pleaÅ¿ed him) have pardoned Å¿in without Å¿atisfaction; or he might have accounted that for Å¿atisfactioÌ, which himÅ¿elf would accept for Å¿atisfaction, be it more or leÅ¿Å¿e; and Å¿o the blood of bulls and goats might have Å¿atisfied as well as the blood of a man, and the blood of a meer man (Å¿uch as my AntagoniÅ¿t would have ChriÅ¿t to be) as well as the blood of ChriÅ¿t who is God and man; but this comes not home to the point; for we are to conÅ¿ider what Å¿atisfaction is now neceÅ¿Å¿ary, & not what might at firÅ¿t have been accepted of.

2. Satisfaction that will now be admitted of and accepted, is Å¿atisfaction according to the Law, that holds proportion to it; for the Law is Gods Law, which flowed from Gods righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and holineÅ¿Å¿e, and in which, and to which, God hath limited himÅ¿elf, and bound up himÅ¿elf, Å¿o that God muÅ¿t deny his own Law, and his own Truth, righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and holineÅ¿Å¿e that is in it, if he do in the leaÅ¿t kind wave that Å¿atisfaction that it requires. 3. What ever that evill is that reprobated, perÅ¿ons doe or Å¿hall endure, upon whom the curÅ¿e of the law is laid, and the death threatned, lighteth becauÅ¿e they were in Adams loynes, when he fell under the threatning

The conÅ¿equence of this, is, that ChriÅ¿ts Å¿ufferings were not the Å¿ufferings of a meer man; for had ChriÅ¿t
been but a meer man, his Å¿ufferings for all the Elect could not have been proportionable to their guilt & demerit. For the righteous God (which without reÅ¿pect of perÅ¿ons, had laid all men under the Å¿ame curÅ¿e and wrath, becauÅ¿e of the Å¿ame Å¿in and guilt, which without difference, all were under) could not Å¿ave by ChriÅ¿t without tranÅ¿mitting that curÅ¿e and wrath which was due to all and every of the Elect to ChriÅ¿t and if ChriÅ¿t had been but a meer man, then there would have been need of Å¿o many ChriÅ¿ts to have Å¿uffered and endured as there are Elect perÅ¿ons; and every one of theÅ¿e ChriÅ¿ts muÅ¿t have Å¿uffered hel, viz. the torments of hell as well as death, and then they muÅ¿t have Å¿uffered ever alÅ¿o, without any end, and yet could not have juÅ¿tified the Elect, becauÅ¿e while they Å¿hould be Å¿uffering till that be ended, God could not be Å¿atisfied; and if God could not be Å¿atisfied, the Elect could not be juÅ¿tified and diÅ¿charged, and Å¿o to all eternity the Elect could not be acquitted; and this appears in ChriÅ¿t, if he had Å¿uffered and had never got through his Å¿uffering we had never been Å¿aved; if he had dyed, and had never riÅ¿en, we had never riÅ¿en to life and glory.

The righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e is in Scripture called ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , Rom. 5 18. which Å¿ignifies a juÅ¿t Å¿atisfaction, or Å¿atisfaction according to the exactneÅ¿Å¿e of juÅ¿tice; and Gods Å¿cope is thereby to declare himÅ¿elf juÅ¿t, that is to magnifie his juÅ¿tice thereby, Rom. 3. 26.

By all this that hath been preÅ¿ented, it appeares how Å¿leight and weak he is in his anÅ¿wer to an Argument of the higheÅ¿t weight, and moment.
